name: Bangkok
fun_fact: Fun fact: Bangkok has the longest city name in the world - its ceremonial name in Thai has 169 letters! Thais call it 'Krung Thep' meaning 'City of Angels', and its street food scene was so celebrated that a $5 street stall won a Michelin star (Jay Fai, the legendary Ratchawong crab omelette lady)!

hero_dishes.name: Pad Thai
hero_dishes.description: Stir-fried rice noodles with shrimp, tofu, egg, tamarind, fish sauce, and peanuts
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created in the 1930s-40s as a nation-building dish to promote Thai identity. Now the most famous Thai dish globally, but locals prefer other noodles
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Thip Samai (legendary, since 1966), Pad Thai Mae Am, street vendors on Khao San Road

hero_dishes.name: Tom Yum Goong
hero_dishes.description: Hot and sour soup with shrimp, lemongrass, galangal, kaffir lime, and chilies
hero_dishes.origin_story: The essential Thai flavor profile - sour, spicy, salty, sweet all at once. The creamy version adds coconut milk
hero_dishes.where_to_find: PE Aor (famous tom yum), Krua Apsorn, most restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Som Tam
hero_dishes.description: Green papaya salad pounded in a mortar with chili, lime, fish sauce, and tomatoes
hero_dishes.origin_story: Originally from Isaan (northeastern Thailand), now ubiquitous. The pounding in a mortar is key - the sound fills streets
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Som Tam Nua, street vendors everywhere, Isaan restaurants

hero_dishes.name: Khao Pad
hero_dishes.description: Thai fried rice with egg, vegetables, and your choice of meat
hero_dishes.origin_story: The everyday Thai meal - simple, quick, and satisfying. Often eaten for breakfast
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Every street vendor and restaurant - it's the default order

signature_drinks.name: Thai Iced Tea (Cha Yen)
signature_drinks.description: Strong black tea with condensed milk and evaporated milk over ice, bright orange color
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: From street vendors in plastic bags with straws, or in tall glasses at restaurants

signature_drinks.name: Chang/Singha/Leo Beer
signature_drinks.description: Thailand's big three beers - light lagers perfect for spicy food
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Ice cold with ice cubes IN the beer - essential in Bangkok heat

food_culture_notes: Street food is disappearing from some areas but Chinatown (Yaowarat) is still incredible
Thais eat 4-5 small meals daily rather than 3 big ones
Fish sauce (nam pla) is in everything - the signature Thai umami
Michelin-starred street food exists - Jay Fai, Raan Jay Fai
